description: ULTIMATE professional-grade pharmacogenomics knowledge base - comprehensive coverage of all clinically-relevant and research-grade PGx variants detectable on 23andMe v5 platform. Includes CPIC Level A/B, FDA-labeled markers, and promising research variants.
methodology: Curated from CPIC, PharmGKB, FDA labels, and peer-reviewed literature. Includes actionable variants (CPIC A/B, FDA-labeled), emerging biomarkers (CPIC C, PharmGKB 2A), and research markers with promising evidence.

interpretation.plain_language: ABCB1 C3435T may affect P-glycoprotein expression and drug transport. Clinical significance controversial - inconsistent findings across studies. May influence digoxin, immunosuppressant levels.
interpretation.clinical_action: No strong clinical recommendations. May consider in context of other factors for drugs with narrow therapeutic index.

interpretation.plain_language: ABCB1 variant potentially affecting P-gp function. Clinical significance uncertain.
interpretation.clinical_action: No strong clinical recommendations

interpretation.plain_language: ABCG2 Q141K reduces transporter function (~50%). Common in East Asians (~30%). Affects rosuvastatin levels (FDA-labeled), uric acid excretion (increased gout risk), and various drug transports. AA genotype: 2x higher rosuvastatin exposure.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ ROSUVASTATIN: AA genotype: Start with 5mg (vs 10mg) or use alternative statin. Increased myopathy risk. Monitor closely. Gout: AA genotype associated with increased hyperuricemia risk - may affect urate-lowering therapy choice.

interpretation.plain_language: ADH1B*2 (His48) metabolizes alcohol 40x faster than Arg48. Common in East Asians (~70%). Causes alcohol flushing response, protective against alcoholism. Affects disulfiram (Antabuse) response.
interpretation.clinical_action: Alcohol use disorder: His48 carriers less likely to develop AUD. Disulfiram more effective. Consider in treatment planning.
limitations: Protective allele - not a toxicity risk

interpretation.plain_language: ADRB2 Arg16Gly affects beta-2 receptor function and response to asthma medications. Gly16 homozygotes may have reduced response to long-acting beta agonists.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ Asthma: Gly/Gly may have better response to leukotriene inhibitors vs LABAs. Consider in treatment algorithm.

interpretation.plain_language: ADRB2 Gln27Glu affects receptor function. Interacts with Arg16Gly.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider with Arg16Gly for asthma treatment

interpretation.plain_language: ALDH2*2 (Lys504) causes aldehyde dehydrogenase deficiency. VERY COMMON in East Asians (~40% heterozygous, ~5% homozygous). Causes alcohol flushing syndrome, strongly protective against alcoholism. Also affects nitroglycerin efficacy (requires ALDH2 for activation).
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ NITROGLYCERIN: *2/*2 homozygotes have reduced response - may need alternative vasodilator (isosorbide). Alcohol: Strongly recommend avoidance due to carcinogenic acetaldehyde accumulation. *2 carriers have increased esophageal cancer risk with alcohol.
limitations: Extremely important in East Asian populations

interpretation.plain_language: ANKK1 Taq1A (near DRD2) associated with reduced striatal D2 receptor density. A1 allele linked to substance abuse, reward sensitivity. May affect antipsychotic response and naltrexone efficacy for alcoholism.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker: A1 carriers may need higher antipsychotic doses, may respond better to naltrexone for alcohol use disorder.

interpretation.plain_language: CHRNA3 D398N (and nearby CHRNA5 variants in LD) strongly affect nicotine dependence. Risk allele carriers smoke more cigarettes per day, have higher nicotine dependence. May affect varenicline (Chantix) response.
interpretation.clinical_action: Smoking cessation: Risk allele carriers may benefit more from pharmacotherapy (varenicline/bupropion) vs behavioral alone.

interpretation.plain_language: CHRNA5 D398N reduces nicotinic receptor function. Strongest GWAS hit for smoking quantity/dependence. Risk allele carriers smoke more.
interpretation.clinical_action: High-risk allele carriers benefit from intensive cessation support

interpretation.plain_language: COMT Val158Met affects dopamine/norepinephrine breakdown. Met/Met (AA) = slow metabolizers, higher baseline dopamine in prefrontal cortex. May affect ADHD medication response, pain sensitivity, and opioid requirements.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ ADHD medications: Met/Met may respond better to lower stimulant doses. Pain management: Met/Met may require lower opioid doses. Parkinson's COMT inhibitors: Consider genotype for dosing.

interpretation.plain_language: CYP1A2*1F causes increased enzyme inducibility. AA genotype = fast caffeine metabolizer. Affects clozapine (antipsychotic) metabolism. Fast metabolizers clear caffeine quickly, may have increased cardiovascular risk with high coffee intake.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ CLOZAPINE: Fast metabolizers may need higher doses. Slow metabolizers (CC): Start lower, monitor for toxicity. Caffeine: Fast metabolizers (AA) may consume more coffee without effects.

interpretation.plain_language: CYP1A2*1C may reduce enzyme activity. Affects caffeine and drug metabolism.
interpretation.clinical_action: Slow metabolizers may need dose adjustments for CYP1A2 substrates

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2A6*9 reduces enzyme activity. Affects nicotine metabolism rate.
interpretation.clinical_action: Smoking cessation counseling - slow metabolizers may benefit from non-NRT approaches

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2A6*2 gene deletion causes complete loss of function. Slow nicotine metabolizers smoke less, have easier time quitting. Also affects coumarin metabolism (not commonly used drug).
interpretation.clinical_action: Smoking cessation: Slow metabolizers may have better success with behavioral therapy vs nicotine replacement. Letrozole: May have altered levels.
limitations: Primarily relevant for smoking cessation pharmacotherapy

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2B6*6 reduces enzyme activity (~30% of normal). Common in all populations (20-60%). TT genotype associated with higher efavirenz levels and increased CNS side effects (dizziness, abnormal dreams, confusion). Important for HIV treatment.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ EFAVIRENZ: TT genotype: Consider dose reduction to 400mg/day (vs 600mg standard) or use alternative antiretroviral. Increased CNS toxicity risk. Monitor closely for neuropsychiatric effects. Bupropion: May need dose reduction. Methadone: Higher doses may be needed.
limitations: Efavirenz being phased out due to toxicity

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2B6*4 increases enzyme expression. Rapid metabolizers clear CYP2B6 substrates faster.
interpretation.clinical_action: Efavirenz/nevirapine: May need higher doses. Methadone: May need dose increases.

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2B6 rs2279343 is part of the *4 (increased function) and *6 (decreased function) haplotypes. Must be phased with rs3745274 to determine allele.
CYP2B6*18 causes complete loss of enzyme function. Primarily found in African populations. Affects efavirenz, nevirapine, and methadone metabolism.
limitations: Important for HIV antiretroviral therapy in African ancestry

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2B6*5 causes loss of function.
interpretation.clinical_action: Efavirenz: dose reduction or alternative

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2B6*9 reduces enzyme activity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider dose adjustments

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*17 is a gain-of-function promoter variant (~20% in Europeans). Increases enzyme expression 2-4 fold. Ultrarapid metabolizers may have better clopidogrel response but reduced PPI/SSRI efficacy.
interpretation.clinical_action: Clopidogrel: Enhanced activation (beneficial). PPIs: May need higher doses for H. pylori eradication. SSRIs: May need higher doses, monitor for inadequate response.
limitations: Clinical significance for SSRIs still debated

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*5 causes loss of function. Rare.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2/*3 - avoid clopidogrel

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*8 splice variant causes loss of function.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2/*3

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*3 causes complete loss of function. Common in East Asian populations (~5-10%), rare in Europeans (<1%).
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2 - avoid clopidogrel, reduce PPI/SSRI doses

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*4 causes loss of function. Rare (~0.2-1%).
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2/*3 - avoid clopidogrel

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*6 frameshift causes loss of function. Rare.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2/*3 - avoid clopidogrel

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*9 causes loss of function.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *2/*3

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C19*2 is the most common loss-of-function variant (~15% in Europeans, 30% in Asians). Causes complete loss of enzyme function. CRITICAL for clopidogrel activation.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ CLOPIDOGREL: FDA BOXED WARNING - Use alternative (prasugrel/ticagrelor). Poor metabolizers have 3x increased cardiovascular event risk. PPIs: Reduce dose 50%. SSRIs: Reduce dose, monitor QT interval.
limitations: Complete phenotype requires assessment of *17 and other alleles

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C8*3 reduces enzyme activity. Affects paclitaxel (chemotherapy) clearance and antidiabetic drug metabolism.
interpretation.clinical_action: Paclitaxel: May have increased toxicity with *3/*3. Antidiabetics: May affect glucose control.

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C8*3 haplotype marker (together with rs28371759).
interpretation.clinical_action: Part of *3 haplotype assessment

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C9*14 causes reduced activity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Warfarin dose reduction

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C9*11 causes reduced enzyme activity affecting warfarin metabolism.
CYP2C9*2 reduces enzyme activity to ~30% of normal. Common in Europeans (~10-15%). CRITICAL for warfarin dosing - reduces metabolism, increases bleeding risk.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ WARFARIN: Start with 25% dose reduction (3-4mg vs 5mg). Monitor INR closely. May need 30-50% lower maintenance dose. Phenytoin: Reduce dose, monitor levels. NSAIDs: Increased GI bleeding risk.
limitations: Warfarin dosing algorithms incorporate both CYP2C9 and VKORC1

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C9*6 frameshift deletion causes complete loss of enzyme function. Rare but important.
CYP2C9*5 is a loss-of-function allele primarily found in African populations.
limitations: Important for warfarin dosing in African ancestry

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C9*3 causes severe reduction in enzyme activity (~10% of normal). Common in Europeans (~5-10%). *3 has stronger effect than *2. Homozygotes or compound heterozygotes are poor metabolizers.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ WARFARIN: Start with 50% dose reduction (0.5-2mg). *2/*3 or *3/*3 need very low doses. Major bleeding risk with standard dosing. Monitor INR twice weekly initially.
limitations: Multiple variants should be assessed together

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2C9*8 causes reduced enzyme activity. Found primarily in African populations.
CYP2C9*13 causes reduced activity. Rare.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider for warfarin dosing

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*29 causes decreased enzyme activity through altered splicing.
CYP2D6*9 is a 3bp deletion causing decreased enzyme activity (about 50% of normal).
CYP2D6*2 is a normal function allele with a silent polymorphism. Used as a haplotype marker.
limitations: Part of comprehensive CYP2D6 diplotype assessment

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*14 frameshift/splicing defect causing no function. Rare but important.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as other no-function alleles

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*17 causes decreased enzyme activity. Common in African populations (20-35%).
CYP2D6*10 causes significantly reduced enzyme activity (~25% of normal). Common in East Asian populations (40-50%). Affects 25% of all prescription drugs.
interpretation.clinical_action: Codeine/tramadol: Consider alternative analgesic. Tamoxifen: Consider higher dose or aromatase inhibitor. SSRIs/TCAs: Start at 50-75% dose. Monitor closely.
limitations: Complete phenotyping requires assessment of multiple CYP2D6 variants
CNV analysis needed for gene duplications/deletions

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6 haplotype tagging SNP.
interpretation.clinical_action: Part of comprehensive haplotype analysis

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*49 causes decreased function. Less common variant.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider dose adjustments

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*6 frameshift deletion causes complete loss of function. Common in Europeans (~1%).
limitations: Results in poor metabolizer phenotype when present

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6 haplotype tagging SNP used in combination with other variants.
interpretation.clinical_action: Part of comprehensive haplotype analysis

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*4 is the most common non-functional allele in Europeans (~20% carrier frequency). Causes complete loss of enzyme function. Homozygotes are poor metabolizers.
interpretation.clinical_action: AVOID codeine/tramadol - no analgesic effect, potential toxicity risk. Tamoxifen: Consider aromatase inhibitor. TCAs/SSRIs: Reduce dose 50-75%. Beta-blockers: Consider alternatives.
limitations: Poor metabolizers need comprehensive drug review

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*8 frameshift causes loss of function. Relatively common in some populations.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *4 - avoid codeine/tramadol

interpretation.plain_language: CYP2D6*3 is a frameshift deletion causing complete loss of enzyme function. Significantly affects drug metabolism of codeine, tamoxifen, and many antidepressants.
CYP2D6*41 causes decreased enzyme activity through splicing defects. Common in Europeans (8-10%).
CYP3A4*20 reduces enzyme activity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider for CYP3A4 substrate dosing

interpretation.plain_language: CYP3A4*22 reduces enzyme expression by ~30%. Affects tacrolimus, simvastatin, and many other CYP3A4 substrates. Heterozygotes have moderately decreased metabolism.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ Tacrolimus/cyclosporine: May need lower doses. Statins: Increased levels, monitor for myopathy. Consider for drug-drug interaction risk assessment.
limitations: CYP3A4 highly inducible by many drugs/foods

interpretation.plain_language: CYP3A5*3 splice variant causes CYP3A5 non-expression. CC genotype = non-expresser (~80% Europeans, ~30% Africans). TT genotype = expresser (metabolizes drugs faster, needs higher tacrolimus doses). Important for immunosuppression after organ transplant.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ TACROLIMUS: TT (expresser): 1.5-2x higher starting dose needed (0.3mg/kg vs 0.2mg/kg). More frequent dose adjustments. Monitor trough levels closely. CC (non-expresser): Standard dosing more likely to achieve target. Ancestry affects frequency dramatically.
limitations: Tacrolimus dosing still requires therapeutic drug monitoring

interpretation.plain_language: CYP3A5*6 splice variant causes non-expression. Found primarily in African populations (~10%).
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *3 - affects tacrolimus dosing

interpretation.plain_language: CYP3A5*7 frameshift causes non-expression. Rare variant.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *3/*6

interpretation.plain_language: CYP3A7*1C causes continued CYP3A7 expression in adults (normally fetal enzyme). May affect metabolism of CYP3A7-specific substrates.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - clinical significance under investigation

interpretation.plain_language: DPYD*4 may cause reduced activity. Clinical significance still being evaluated.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider dose reduction or closer monitoring

interpretation.plain_language: DPYD*2A causes complete DPD enzyme deficiency. CRITICAL: Carriers have severe, potentially FATAL toxicity from 5-FU and capecitabine chemotherapy. This is an FDA-labeled pharmacogenomic marker.
limitations: CRITICAL SAFETY - testing required before fluoropyrimidine chemotherapy

interpretation.plain_language: DPYD c.2846A>T causes reduced DPD activity (~50%). Carriers require 50% dose reduction of fluoropyrimidines. FDA-labeled variant.
DPYD*13 (I560S) causes complete DPD deficiency. CRITICAL: Associated with severe 5-FU toxicity. FDA-labeled variant.
limitations: CRITICAL SAFETY - avoid fluoropyrimidines in carriers

interpretation.plain_language: DPYD HapB3 haplotype causes reduced DPD activity. Associated with increased 5-FU toxicity risk. Requires dose reduction.
DRD2 C957T affects receptor mRNA stability. May influence antipsychotic response.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL: G6PD deficiency causes hemolytic anemia with oxidative stress drugs. X-linked. Males are hemizygous (affected if have variant). Females are carriers/affected if homozygous. Common in Mediterranean, African, Asian populations (antimalarial protection). MANDATORY testing before primaquine.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ AVOID: Primaquine, rasburicase, dapsone, nitrofurantoin, sulfonamides. Use alternatives. Hemolysis can be SEVERE, potentially fatal. Screen before antimalarial therapy. Avoid fava beans, oxidative stress.

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ G6PD deficiency variant. Often occurs with rs1050828 (A- haplotype).
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ Same as rs1050828 - avoid oxidative drugs

interpretation.plain_language: GSTM1 null genotype (~50% of people) lack GST-M1 enzyme. May affect chemotherapy toxicity and carcinogen detoxification.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - limited clinical actionability
limitations: Gene deletion not well-detected on SNP arrays

interpretation.plain_language: GSTP1 I105V affects glutathione S-transferase Pi, important for chemotherapy detoxification. Val/Val may have altered platinum chemo toxicity/efficacy.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker for chemotherapy response. Not clinically implemented.

interpretation.plain_language: Near HLA-B*57:01, associated with flucloxacillin hepatotoxicity. Strong GWAS signal.
interpretation.clinical_action: Monitor liver function if on flucloxacillin
limitations: Flucloxacillin not commonly used in US

interpretation.plain_language: HLA-A*31:01 associated with carbamazepine hypersensitivity in Northern Europeans. Different from HLA-B*15:02 (Asian-specific). May cause DRESS syndrome, SJS/TEN.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ European ancestry: Consider alternative anticonvulsant if HLA-A*31:01 positive. FDA awareness statement.
limitations: Lower risk than HLA-B*15:02 in Asians

interpretation.plain_language: HLA-B*13:01 associated with dapsone hypersensitivity syndrome in Asian populations.
interpretation.clinical_action: Monitor closely if on dapsone

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL: HLA-B*57:01 positive patients have 50-90% risk of severe, potentially FATAL hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir (HIV drug). Symptoms: fever, rash, GI, respiratory distress within 1-6 weeks. Can be fatal if rechallenge. MANDATORY pretreatment testing.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ CRITICAL: HLA-B*57:01 positive: NEVER prescribe abacavir. Use alternative ARV. FDA BLACK BOX WARNING. MANDATORY testing before abacavir. If positive, document in medical record.
limitations: rs2395029 is imperfect proxy - direct HLA-B*57:01 typing preferred

interpretation.plain_language: ⚠️ HLA-B*58:01 strongly predicts severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCAR) to allopurinol, including SJS/TEN. 100-fold increased risk. VERY COMMON in Han Chinese (~10%), less in Europeans (~1%).
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ STRONG RECOMMENDATION: Test before allopurinol in Asian patients. If positive, use alternative (febuxostat, pegloticase). CPIC recommends allopurinol-alternative for B*58:01 carriers.
limitations: rs2276707 is proxy - direct HLA-B*58:01 typing better

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL: HLA-B*15:02 carriers have dramatically increased risk of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) from carbamazepine. SJS/TEN are life-threatening skin reactions (mortality ~30%). VERY COMMON in East/Southeast Asians (~10%). FDA recommends testing for Asian patients.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ CRITICAL: HLA-B*15:02 positive: AVOID carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin. Use alternatives (valproate, levetiracetam, lamotrigine). FDA recommendation for Asian ancestry. If SJS/TEN occurs, NEVER rechallenge.
limitations: rs3909184 is proxy - direct HLA-B*15:02 typing better

interpretation.plain_language: HLA-DQA1*05:01 associated with increased lapatinib (breast cancer drug) hepatotoxicity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Monitor liver function closely if positive

interpretation.plain_language: HLA-DRB1*07:01 associated with lapatinib hepatotoxicity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Monitor liver function

interpretation.plain_language: HTR2A His452Tyr affects receptor signaling. May influence clozapine response.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker

interpretation.plain_language: HTR2A T102C may affect SSRI and atypical antipsychotic response. Meta-analyses show modest associations with antidepressant efficacy.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - not clinically implemented

interpretation.plain_language: IFNL3/IL28B variant predicts Hepatitis C treatment response to interferon-based therapy. CC genotype: 2-3x higher sustained virologic response (SVR) vs TT. Less relevant now with DAAs (direct-acting antivirals) which have >95% cure rate regardless of genotype.
interpretation.clinical_action: Historical importance: CC favorable for interferon. Modern: DAAs (sofosbuvir, ledipasvir) preferred regardless of genotype. May still influence DAA treatment duration in some cases.
limitations: Less relevant with modern DAA therapy
Still used for treatment duration decisions

interpretation.plain_language: MTHFR A1298C has milder effect than C677T. Compound heterozygotes (677T/1298C) have additive reduction in activity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider in combination with C677T for methotrexate risk assessment

interpretation.plain_language: MTHFR C677T reduces enzyme activity 30-70%. TT genotype = thermolabile variant. Important for methotrexate (chemotherapy/RA drug) toxicity risk. Also affects folate metabolism and homocysteine levels.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ METHOTREXATE: TT genotype may have increased toxicity risk (mucositis, myelosuppression). Ensure adequate folate supplementation. Monitor closely. May need dose reduction.

interpretation.plain_language: MTRR A66G affects methionine synthase reductase, involved in B12-dependent homocysteine metabolism. May interact with MTHFR for methotrexate toxicity.
interpretation.clinical_action: Consider with MTHFR status for methotrexate risk assessment

interpretation.plain_language: NAT2 slow acetylator status affects drug metabolism and toxicity risk. Two slow alleles = slow acetylator (~50% Europeans, ~10% Asians). Slow acetylators have 3-4x increased isoniazid hepatotoxicity risk and higher peripheral neuropathy risk.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ ISONIAZID: Slow acetylators: Vitamin B6 supplementation (25-50mg daily) MANDATORY to prevent peripheral neuropathy. Monitor liver function monthly. Consider shorter TB treatment if slow acetylator. Hydralazine/procainamide: Increased lupus-like syndrome risk.
limitations: Multiple NAT2 variants determine acetylator status

interpretation.plain_language: NAT2*14 slow acetylator allele.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as other slow acetylator alleles

interpretation.plain_language: NAT2*6 is a slow acetylator allele. Affects metabolism of isoniazid, sulfonamides, and hydralazine. Slow acetylators have increased isoniazid hepatotoxicity risk.
NAT2*7 slow acetylator allele.
interpretation.clinical_action: Same as *5/*6

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL: NUDT15*4 causes enzyme deficiency. Less common than *2/*3.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ Same as *2/*3

interpretation.plain_language: NUDT15*3 (R139C) is the most common East Asian loss-of-function variant. CRITICAL: Associated with severe thiopurine toxicity. FDA-labeled.
limitations: CRITICAL SAFETY - most important NUDT15 variant to test

interpretation.plain_language: NUDT15*2 causes complete loss of enzyme function. CRITICAL: Homozygotes have severe early leukopenia from thiopurines. Common in East Asian populations (10% carrier frequency). FDA-labeled pharmacogenomic marker.
limitations: CRITICAL SAFETY - avoid thiopurines or use 10% dose in homozygotes

interpretation.plain_language: OPRM1 A118G may affect opioid analgesic response and addiction risk. GG genotype may require higher opioid doses for analgesia. Also associated with alcohol dependence risk.
interpretation.clinical_action: May consider in pain management - GG patients may need higher doses. Not definitive.

interpretation.plain_language: PON1 Q192R affects paraoxonase 1 enzyme that detoxifies organophosphates. RR genotype has higher activity against certain substrates (paraoxon) but lower against others.
interpretation.clinical_action: Relevant for occupational/military exposure to organophosphates. May affect sarin/VX detoxification capacity.

interpretation.plain_language: PON1 L55M affects enzyme levels. Interacts with Q192R.
interpretation.clinical_action: Part of PON1 haplotype assessment

interpretation.plain_language: SLC19A1/RFC1 variant may affect methotrexate transport and toxicity. Clinical significance under investigation.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - no clinical recommendations yet

interpretation.plain_language: SLC6A4 STin2 (with 5-HTTLPR VNTR) affects serotonin transporter expression. May influence SSRI response and adverse effects.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - STAR*D trial showed associations but not clinically implemented
limitations: Needs 5-HTTLPR VNTR which SNP arrays don't detect well

interpretation.plain_language: SLCO1B1*5 (V174A) reduces hepatic statin uptake, increasing blood levels and myopathy risk. STRONGEST genetic predictor of statin myopathy. CC genotype: 17-fold increased simvastatin myopathy risk at 80mg dose, 4-fold at 40mg. FDA-labeled.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ SIMVASTATIN: CC genotype: AVOID >40mg dose. Use ≤20mg or switch to pravastatin/rosuvastatin. CT: Use ≤40mg. Atorvastatin: Lower doses preferred if CC. Pravastatin/rosuvastatin: Less affected, preferred alternatives.
limitations: Simvastatin most affected, pravastatin/rosuvastatin least affected

interpretation.plain_language: SLCO1B1*1b is a common haplotype marker. When combined with rs4149056 (C), defines the *15 and *17 decreased function haplotypes.
SLCO1B3 variant, clinical significance unclear.
interpretation.clinical_action: No clinical recommendations

interpretation.plain_language: SLCO1B3 promoter variant.
interpretation.clinical_action: No clinical recommendations

interpretation.plain_language: SLCO1B3 variant, may affect transport function.
interpretation.clinical_action: No clinical recommendations

interpretation.plain_language: SLCO1B3 variant may affect drug transport. Less well-studied than SLCO1B1.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker

interpretation.plain_language: TLR4 D299G affects Toll-like receptor 4 function, important for bacterial LPS recognition. May affect sepsis risk and response to Gram-negative infections.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - no clinical recommendations. May affect vaccine response.

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL: TPMT variant causing enzyme deficiency. Part of *3A (with rs1800460) or *3C alone. Same critical safety implications as rs1800460.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ CRITICAL: Same as rs1800460 - avoid or drastically reduce thiopurines

interpretation.plain_language: TPMT*2 causes complete loss of enzyme function. CRITICAL: Homozygotes have severe, potentially fatal toxicity risk from thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP, thioguanine).
TPMT*3D causes enzyme deficiency. Less common than *3A.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ Same as other TPMT deficiency alleles - avoid/reduce thiopurines

interpretation.plain_language: ⛔ CRITICAL SAFETY FINDING: TPMT deficiency causes SEVERE, POTENTIALLY FATAL bone marrow toxicity from thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP, thioguanine). Used for autoimmune diseases, IBD, ALL. Deficiency frequency: ~0.3% homozygous, ~10% heterozygous. This is MANDATORY pretreatment testing.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⛔ CRITICAL: Homozygous deficient (e.g. *3A/*3A): AVOID thiopurines or reduce to 10% dose with intensive monitoring. Heterozygous: 30-80% dose reduction, weekly CBC × 4 weeks. LIFE-THREATENING myelosuppression risk.

interpretation.plain_language: TYMS variants may affect 5-fluorouracil efficacy (cancer treatment). Higher TYMS expression associated with 5-FU resistance.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - not clinically implemented

interpretation.plain_language: TYMS 5'UTR VNTR affects thymidylate synthase expression and 5-FU efficacy.
interpretation.clinical_action: Research marker - not clinically implemented

interpretation.plain_language: UGT1A1*28 (7 TA repeats vs normal 6) causes reduced enzyme expression (~30% activity). Homozygotes have Gilbert syndrome (mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia). CRITICAL for irinotecan chemotherapy - significantly increased severe diarrhea and neutropenia risk. ~10% Europeans homozygous.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ IRINOTECAN: *28/*28 homozygous: Reduce starting dose by 30%. Monitor closely for severe diarrhea/neutropenia. FDA-labeled. Heterozygous: Standard dose but monitor closely. Gilbert syndrome: Benign, no treatment needed, avoid fasting.
limitations: TA repeat may not be well-detected on SNP arrays

interpretation.plain_language: UGT1A1*6 common in East Asian populations (~20%). Causes Gilbert-like syndrome and increased irinotecan toxicity.
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ Irinotecan: Reduce dose by 30% if homozygous

interpretation.plain_language: UGT1A1*27 reduces enzyme activity. African-specific variant.
interpretation.clinical_action: Monitor irinotecan toxicity

interpretation.plain_language: VKORC1 -1639G>A is THE most important warfarin sensitivity variant. T allele (low-dose haplotype) causes significantly increased warfarin sensitivity. TT genotype needs ~30-50% lower warfarin dose. FDA-labeled. Explains ~25% of warfarin dose variance (CYP2C9 + VKORC1 together explain ~40%).
interpretation.clinical_action: ⚠️ WARFARIN: TT genotype: Start 0.5-2mg, target 2-3mg maintenance. CT: Start 3-4mg, target 3-5mg. CC: Standard 5-7mg dosing. Monitor INR 2-3x weekly initially. Use warfarin dosing algorithms (IWPC, Gage) incorporating both VKORC1 and CYP2C9.
limitations: Must be used WITH CYP2C9 status
Other factors affect dosing (age, weight, interacting meds)
